newsitem.title: UK: Hong Kong stocks nudge lower in quiet London trade.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks nudge lower in quiet London trade.

text.p: Hong Kong shares edged lower in quiet London trading on Thursday, amid profit-taking and concerns about recent speculative attacks on the Hong Kong dollar and other regional currencies, dealers said.
The Hang Seng London Reference index fell 50.83 points or 0.3 percent to 15,658.40, after the Hang Seng fell 29.58 or 0.2 percent to 15,709.23 after initially reaching a record 15,880.57.
Dealers said attention on Friday would likely focus on a meeting of Asian central bankers in Shanghai to discuss the region's currency woes.
"Everyone is waiting for the central banks meeting," said one dealer, "people want to hear what Japan has to say and tomorrow is D-Day."

The dealer said Hong Kong could not be completely insulated from the turmoil gripping currencies in the region and noted that it had already nudged up lending rates to help deter speculative selling of the currency.
Elsewhere the market was quiet with prices pulled lower by a weak start on Wall Street.
"There is nothing spectacular, we are just following the Street lower...it is just another quiet day in London," said another dealer.
